metadata.title: Convert Radians to Degrees – Angle Converter
metadata.description: Convert angles from Radians to Degrees, useful for interpreting mathematical results in familiar units.

introduction: This converter transforms mathematical radian angles to familiar degrees for easy interpretation.
Radians are standard in mathematics but degrees are more intuitive for everyday angles.
This converter uses the relationship where π radians equals 180 degrees.
methodology: π radians = 180°. To convert radians to degrees: multiply by 180/π.
Radians are natural for calculus but degrees help visualize angles practically.
Understanding radian-to-degree conversion bridges mathematical and practical understanding.
This converter provides precise angle conversion for practical interpretation.
examples: Example 1 – Right angle: π/2 radians ≈ 1.571 rad = 90°.

faqs.question: Why do physicists use radians?
faqs.answer: Radians simplify physics equations. Angular velocity = velocity/radius, only works with radians.

faqs.question: Is π radians really exactly 180°?
faqs.answer: Yes, by definition. Radian: angle with arc length = radius. Semicircle: arc = πr, angle = π rad.

faqs.question: What's the easiest way to remember conversion?
How do sine and cosine work in radians?
faqs.answer: Sin(π/6) = 0.5, cos(π/4) = 0.707. Same trig ratios, angles just expressed differently.

faqs.question: What's a common mistake with radians?
faqs.answer: Forgetting to set calculator to RAD mode. Double-check mode before calculations.

faqs.question: Do all programming languages use radians?
faqs.answer: Yes. Java, Python, C, JavaScript all use radians in Math.sin(), math.sin(), etc.

faqs.question: What is a milliradian?
faqs.answer: 1/1000 of a radian. Used in engineering and military applications for precision angles.

faqs.question: How do I convert between degree minutes seconds?
faqs.answer: First convert DMS to decimal degrees, then use degrees to radians conversion.

glossary.definition: Natural angle unit based on arc length, standard in mathematics.
Angle unit where full circle = 360°, familiar but arbitrary.
Curved portion of circle or curve.
Distance around circle = 2πr. Equals 2π radians at unit radius.
Rate of rotation, typically in radians per second.
